The information shall be provided in writing, or by other means, including, where appropriate, by electronic means. When requested by the data subject, the information may be provided orally, provided that the identity of the data subject is proven by other means. compliant.legal provisions: Right to object: The data subject shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to his or her particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning him or her which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including profiling based on those provisions. The controller shall no longer process the personal data unless the controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.

non_compliant.amend: While not mandatory, it is good practice to include references to relevant guidance from supervisory authorities. This can help data subjects understand how their rights are interpreted and applied in practice. You could add a sentence like: "We also take into account relevant guidance issued by data protection supervisory authorities when interpreting and applying your rights."

The policy should address how potential disputes regarding data protection will be handled. This could include information about the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority. You could add a section like: "Dispute Resolution: If you have any concerns or disputes regarding the processing of your personal data, you have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority, in particular in the Member State of your habitual residence, place of work or place of the alleged infringement. You can find the contact details for your local supervisory authority here: [link to the European Data Protection Board's list of supervisory authorities]."
